abstract: AT&T is said to have been dissuaded by the intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company.
snippet: AT&T is said to have been dissuaded by the intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company.
lead_paragraph: MILAN, April 16 — AT&T on Monday withdrew its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, the largest Italian telecommunications company, for about two billion euros, or $2.7 billion.

headline.main: AT&T Drops Offer to Invest in Italian Phone Company
headline.print_headline: AT&T Drops Offer to Invest In Italian Phone Company

abstract: T. Boone Pickens of BP Capital is “one of the most complex characters in modern-day capitalism,” Portfolio magazine writes in a profile of the self-made oil tycoon, whose son pleaded guilty last year to securities fraud. It describes the hedge fund manager, who earned about $1.5 billion in 2005, as a combination of King Lear, Lazarus, Robin Hood, and Amarillo Slim.
lead_paragraph: T. Boone Pickens of BP Capital is “one of the most complex characters in modern-day capitalism,” Portfolio magazine writes in a profile of the self-made oil tycoon, whose son pleaded guilty last year to securities fraud. It describes the hedge fund manager, who earned about $1.5 billion in 2005, as a combination of King Lear, Lazarus, Robin Hood, and Amarillo Slim.

headline.main: An Oil Mogul and a Family Drama

abstract: AT&T on Monday withdrew its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, the largest Italian telecommunications company, for about two billion euros, or $2.7 billion. In a terse statement, AT&T did not give any reason for the decision to pull back its offer to buy a third of the controlling company, Olimpia. But The New York Times reports that AT&T became disenchanted with the idea following intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company.
lead_paragraph: AT&T on Monday withdrew its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, the largest Italian telecommunications company, for about two billion euros, or $2.7 billion. But The New York Times reports that AT&T became disenchanted with the idea following intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company.

headline.main: AT&T Drops Offer to Invest in Italian Phone Company
